remixed_from.title: Laser Pointer Holder for Buildlog.net 2.x Laser

title: Laser Pointer Holder for 40W CO2 Laser

description.text:
I recently acquire a cheap chinese 40W CO2 laser engraver/cutter. It's great value for its price but not user friendly.  The machine do come with red dot laser side mount next to laser head. It's simple but never line up correctly to the actual CO2 laser light path.   
In the high end laser machine, it use ZnSe or GaAs lens as beam combiner. However, the cost of lens just way too expensive for this low-end machine. So I found [39188] have a great idea to make a lever to drop the red dot laser on the light path when the door is opened. And once the door is closed, the red dot laser will put aside to allow actual CO2 laser to pass through. The addition feature for this design is this also works like "Laser Beam Guard", when the lid is open, it will block the CO2 laser  in case the laser misfired.  
Thus, I start to design my own lever holder and pivot holder for the chinese laser machine.  
I made the pivot holder be a "clip on" device so you can snap on the machine with out modify the laser machine and slide it left/right to adjust it's position.

It's pretty simple and intuitive. Follow the [39188] for more detail I drill and tap two hole to install the spring so laser will drop down once the door lid is opened. These is not in the CAD design because the spring might be vary from what you have on hand. The extension spring I am using is from Harbor Freight "200 Spring Assorted" (http://www.harborfreight.com/200-piece-assorted-spring-set-67562.html)

title: E3D v5 Dual Duct Assembly for Makergear M2 - UPDATED

description.text:
UPDATE: As per several requests I've made a mirrored form of the 30 mm and 40 mm ducts. They are labeled as "Mirrored" and mount the 40 mm duct on the left side of the E3D hot end.
.
Here is a revision to my E3D v5 hotend duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:254004) for a MakerGear M2. Even though this is made for the M2, several folks have told me they’ve been able to implement this on other brands of printers, most notably Robo 3D printers. If there are others that this works on please let me know and if there are specific changes you would like to make this design work better for your printer, don’t hesitate to post a request.
.
I recently made a duct for the E3D v6 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:494430) and made a number of design improvements. For those people that haven’t made the upgrade to the E3D v6, I translated the design improvements to my v5 duct design.
.
The extruder is for 1.75mm filament and I’ve made two versions of the extruder, one to fit 2.0 mm I.D. PTFE (at the top) and one to fit 3.0 mm I.D. PTFE. The reason for the later is because 3.0 mm I.D. PTFE tubing allows kinked filament to pass through this more readily. I’ve uploaded a version of each with and without supports / pads. Most of the supports and pads peel away easily or can be crushed and plucked off with a pair of needle nose pliers. Cleanup should be pretty quick and easy. I suggest that you pass a 2.0 mm diameter circular file down the length of the filament shaft of the extruder. Sometimes there are minor blockages that can lead to filament jams. This design was inspired by both rsilvers’ M2 extruder design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:267137) and cmenard’s adaptation for the E3D v6 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:349859). I’ve tried to fit the extruder to the hot end such that it seats very precisely and does not require much force but you need to come at it at the right angle. It holds the hotend very firmly (better than the E3D v6 extruder, which I’m currently revamping to fit better).
.
I’ve also reduced the size of the restraining block on top of the 30 mm fan duct. This takes the geometry of the E3D v5 extruder I designed into account. I’ve posted ducts with labels on top so you can better keep track of your nozzle diameter if you have multiple hotends.
.
I hope this works as well for you as it does for me. I immediately noticed a significant improvement in the smoothness of my shells and the consistency of extrusion. Please comment if you have any design suggestions or requested fixes.

I suggest that you print the extruder with supports. I've tested this dozens of times and this is the minimum amount of pads and supports needed for a clean print. The support elements should peel away easily and take only a minute or two to clean up. The most time consuming part of the cleanup would be passing a 2 mm diameter circular file down the filament path to clean out any strings that could lead to filament jams.
.
The 40 mm duct prints fine without support but with smaller extrusion nozzle diameters will lead to strings. I've had this print well with 0.35mm diameter nozzles although 0.30mm and 0.25mm diameter nozzles work there is some stringiness (internal).
.
The 30 mm duct has built in supports. I did not provide a version without support because I found this orientation led to the strongest form of the duct and it requires support when printed this way.
.
The parts are very finely fitted so if your printer is off in calibration, you may have difficulty getting the E3D hotend to fit the extruder. I've printed this extruder about 100 times using a variety of plastics with different extruder diameters. This configuration was the one that performed the most consistently in fit and hold.

description.text:
I needed an adapter from a Budaschnozzle to a J-Head type mount for Wired1's "Highly accessible vertXtruder for OB1.4" which is under development still. It doesn't allow for the normal shoe mounting that many Wade type extruders do.
Added a second version for anti-rotation for use with through bolt retainer designs. Left the circular groove version as an alternate.
3/1 Updated the Anti-Rotation version. The screw engagement area diameter on the cylindrical section was was decreased from 2.9mm to 2.75mm which is just enough to get the screws through with a little work and provide stiffer mounting.
This is my first thing and I'm not an exemplary 3D artist in 123D, but I don't have a copy of my favorite program anymore so it's time to learn new things!

Print it, use lots of cooling or delays between layers on the upper parts or it will sag in. I did 40% infill but haven't tested it yet as I'm still building the printer. It's possible that the design may change once I do use it. Hopefully you'll find it usefull for your needs. Suggestions welcome.
Drill the center hole with at least a 3mm bit to clean it up from strings or print size variances, then install.
Support on the groove was difficult to remove, I just slid it up into the vertXtruder body and ran a 3mm drill bit through the screw holes, in reverse, to clear out what I needed.
This will reduce the Z height of the stock OB1.4 printer, I suggest increasing the Z height of the frame a little bit to compensate for it if needed.

My Entry for the #IceBoxChallenge  
This is a simple part that allows you to stack bowls, plates, and containers inside your fridge allowing you to save space and stay organized.  
This design was made with 2.5mm wooden skewers, however the.ipt is included, if you wish to modify the size, or the size of the holes. This can also be done by editing the sizes on the .stl file in a 3D modelling program of your choice..   
If you make one for yourself upload a picture for us to see!
Instructions!

Print with the flat side down
Insert 4 wooden skewers, cut to length
Set part on top of a bowl / container
Start Stacking!

Because I've started experimenting with BuildTak I've noticed that the quality of adhesion to this surface is very dependent on the position of the nozzle relative to the bed. So fine tuning bed height is a must to get this to work right. Because my previous Z-stop (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:254002) wasn't that adjustable or of the right height for the E3Dv6 hotend, I needed to redesign this part.
.
I've posted 3 versions of different length. I use the shortest of them.
.
If you are using BuildTak or a similar surface, I think its really important to be able to make fine adjustments. I noticed that a 1/8 turn on the knob can make a difference between not sticking or sticking too hard. Its that sensitive. But if you get it to work, its the best surface I've used so far.

This part should print fine without need for modification or support.
.
To assemble this, you need to reverse the orientation of the M2's Z-stop screw. You then fix the screw in place with the two nuts, giving room for the Z-stop.
.
As shown in the photos screw the Z-stop on the bolt and you can now finely tune your Z-stop length without having to loosen the two nuts and reposition the bolt.

My first contribution to Thingiverse!
A simple filament holder to append to the top of your QU-BD OneUp or TwoUp.
Doesn't need screws or glue or anything. I placed the main spool into a drawer under the printer and I only take off the filament I need along the day.
I hope this is a good way to preserve it from humidity as my zone is plagued by it.
And I hope somebody will find it useful too!

Just snap it onto the printer!
First pull the side with the longer wing into the top of the printer, then snap it down by pushing the side that houses the filament.
If needed, apply some pressure to the middle of the hooking so to open it a bit.

comments.text: You're the third person to ask that question and the best answer that I have is that this just seemed easier and less likely to break the drill bits. I don't have a machinist's background though so I would love for someone who is to tell me why I'm wrong! :-) I'm having a hard time imagining rotating the nut would break fewer bits. The bits that I'm using for the holes are quite small. It seems that unless the bit landed on the rotating nut at the exact axis of rotation it would be more likely to break because it would effectively be dragging on the rotating nut. At least with the stationary nut, I can land the bit anywhere on the flat and have a chance at getting a hole. What am I missing? Thanks in advance for any insights!

description.text:
If you have made this thing, PLEASE take pictures and post! Thanks. This is a simplified dual axis tracker for small solar projects. Notice that the weight of the tracker is NOT putting pressure on the servo motors. The pitch gear is nestled inside the bracket which reduces wobbliness and makes the installation look professional. For the horizontal gear system it just made sense to attach the entire panel mount directly on the gear. It makes for a really solid structure. This was my first attempt at a project like this. Let me know how it works out if you build one... Enjoy!
Here are video links:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sbksReSEpJc
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HqACH3WS-w8
Here is a simiar project with no printed parts:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Solar-Tracker/

You need: Arduino Uno, (2) SG90 Micro servo motors, (4) LDRs, breadboard, wires, rainbow ribbon cable for LDRs, 4" long 1/4" bolt and nut.
Print all parts.
Attach horizontal servo motor to tracker base before attaching the horizontal gear or you will have trouble with tool access to get the motor mounted. The vertical servo gear should be ok to assemble first due to the smaller size. To mount the gears to the servo motors, I cut tiny brass nails just a bit smaller than the thickness of the gears and made little groves on the nail to give a rough surface for the plastic to bond to. I then used a soldering iron to heat the nail and fuse it through the white servo gear attachment and then into the plastic gear. Makes for a nice, clean installation. Just make sure that your gear is exactly centered when you mount it to the servo.
Attach motors, gears, and panel mount.
Hook up wires according to schematic.
Load program into Arduino and test it out.
Depending on the light that you use to move your tracker around, you might need to change the resistor size on breadboard (they should all be equal value, higher value resistors for less light).

I have an Amiga on which I still enjoy playing old classics. Unfortunately I am having a hard time finding functional joysticks. I found one which was beyond repair, and decided to apply a bit of 3D printing to save it! It does not look good but it works perfectly. Only one button switch worked, so I made it a one button stick. The top of the stick body houses the original switch, and the printed button clips on top. It is quite robust in fact, and works very well (we played Kick Off 2 a full afternoon without trouble!)
I believe many similar models were available back then, so it might help you as well... Enjoy!

There are three parts: the main body, the button and the screw holders. These have
been designed with a round head which is not the best: A square head would make it
easier to tighten the screw after assembly. However it was fine on mine so I did not
fix this. I printed it with a layer size of 0.27 mm on a Replicator1.

What/Why:
The armrest on my lounge/sofa is wide, but does not hold items well. My clumsiness, aswell as my cat often knock things off. This is a small table which will allow teacups, my phone and whatnot to sit on the armrest without being knocked off. How:
Each STL file is 1 quarter of the item. Print 4 to make a full item. Some support material will be required for the slots which allow the peices to interlock. As for the small separate piece on the side, glue them to the bottom of the table, so as to provide a snug fit to your armrest. Photos will be uploaded soon, when I have more time on my hands

title: Emptynoti - alert you when your food is running low (#IceboxChallenge)

description.text:
In the age of touch screen technology we all wish we had a smart refrigerator, alerting us when something is running low or the expiration date is way overdue.
But until everyone will have 20 inch display on their door I want to use a simple method to alert me when something is running low.
For this purpose I introduce "Emptynoti"
One needs only to switch between the correct food status ranging from "full" to "half full" and "empty".
Next time when you go out shopping , open the refrigerator take a glance on Emptynoti and have an idea what you need to buy.
Emptynoti can be hanged in front of every compartment in plain view.
Simple but effective.

title: Fully Printable Printrbot Simple 1405 Classic Z Stop Mod (No Probe)

description.text:
3 parts,   
Using Jon's Y axis extension mod and fully printable base allows a much better printrbot Simple, however it also eliminates the ability to use the class endstop Z homing method rather than the probe.  
I designed two parts in addition to using Jon's already existing Z screw mount.   
You must sandwich the fan mount in between Jon's Y plate and the Z screw mount.   
Mount the remaining piece on the base by screwing it into the motor, then simply place your Z endstop on that mount.   
I have not tested yet, but the parts do line up perfectly so it should work.

title: Make: 2015 3D Printer Shoot Out Test Models

description.text: Make Magazine's third annual 3D Printing Shootout was conducted using these files, created by Andreas Bastian to benchmark performance of desktop 3D printers. You can read all 26 machine reviews in Make:'s Annual Guide to 3D Printing 2015 (Volume 42).

These test geometries are designed to evaluate specific performance characteristics and motion systems in common low-cost FDM/FFF machines.  Traditionally, layer height has been used as a proxy for resolution or quality, but it is a bit of an oversimplification of what is often termed "print quality".

• Dimensional Accuracy
  • Bridging Performance
  • Overhang Performance
  • Negative Space Tolerance
  • Fine Positive Features Performance
  • XY Resonance
  • Z Resonance
Learn how to evaluate the test geometries at: http://wp.me/p22K2I-1TOt

Please use the “I Made One” button on your file sharing site of choice to share your results! Make sure to include the following information with your photo(s) of your completed test prints:
  • Machine make and model
  • Slicer and slicing settings (layer height, number of shells, print temperature, extrusion multipliers, speeds)
  • Print time - start with a room temperature extruder and platform. Begin timing when you start the print, and include the preheat sequence. Keep timing through any post-print sequence, like the extruder or platform returning to a homing position.
  • Filament source

Since I've been experimenting with different surfaces and materials, I've bought new print surfaces like glass and spring steel. Some of these have come in dimensions slightly different than the stock print surface for the Makergear M2. So instead of cutting the rubber pieces that hold the print surface in place, I designed an adjustable bracket that I've been able to use to hold a variety of slightly mis-sized print surfaces. This has been particularly useful with the BuildTak surface as their surface comes slightly larger than my stock glass.  
I've added a version 2 by request for the most recent version of the MakerGear M2.
Just remove the rubber printbed hold downs and slide these in place. Snug them up against the printbed and tighten. Mine hold the print surface very firmly in place.

comments.text: out of curiosity, which print surface works best?
comments.author: Luke321

comments.text: This is not a straight forward question because different materials print better on different surfaces. I've tried traditional things like acetone-ABS, Kapton tape, blue masking tape, glue sticks, and hair spray. Of these Kapton tape with acetone-ABS wiped onto it is a consistent surface for ABS. Acetone-ABS layered onto glass is a consistent surface for PLA. The best results are gotten without printing a raft.

title: 3-Way Elbow, 1/2 Inch PVC Pipe Fitting Series #HalfInchPVCFittings - UPDATED 2015-02-02

description.text:
Here is a 3-Way Elbow designed to fit 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe. It's part of a series of 1/2" PVC fittings I'm designing to supplement conventional plumbing fittings. The 3-Way Elbow can be used to make boxes and various other forms. My original purpose was a small, plastic-wrapped greenhouse to hold plants over the winter.
.
I put the triangular holes in the pipes to help the glue dry. On the first iteration, I noticed that being air tight prohibited drying. The ledges on the top of the horizontal holes make it printable without support structures.
.
I will continue to add new fittings to the series and share them as a derivative of my original 3-Way Elbow. Please let me know if there is a fitting you need that I haven't created yet.
.
You are highly encouraged to make new derivatives. Please tag your new creations with #HalfInchPVCFittings.
.
Update 2015-02-02. I made the side fittings slightly more snug now that my printer is properly calibrated.

title: Reconfigurable 22.5 & 45 Degree 3-Way Elbows, 1/2 Inch PVC Pipe Fitting Series #HalfInchPVCFittings UPDATE 2015-07-03

description.text: UPDATE 2015-07-03: I tightened the tolerances slightly for a better fit. Make sure your printer is well calibrated before printing. Update 2014-11-11: For a more elegant solution that uses less plastic, try out my new adjustable angle 3-way elbow: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537497 Here are reconfigurable 22.5 & 45 degree 3-Way Elbows designed to fit 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe. They are part of a series of 1/2" PVC fittings I'm designing to supplement conventional plumbing fittings. These elbows can be used to make angled roofs for structures and other forms. My original purpose was a roof for a small, plastic-wrapped greenhouse to hold plants over the winter. If you're making a roof, you might notice that each corner requires a different fitting. In order to make one design instead of four, I made the elbows reconfigurable. The 22.5 and 45 degree fittings each allow you to make 4 different elbows and 1 Y fitting. Print 1 of either the 22.5 or the 45 degree fitting, then print 2 sleeves and 2 caps. Slide the sleeves into the holes of your choice and cap the other holes. Glue for a secure fit. I put the triangular holes in the pipes to help the glue dry. On the first iteration, I noticed that being air tight prohibited drying. The ledges on the top of the horizontal holes make it printable without support structures. I will continue to add new fittings to the series and share them as a derivative of my original 3-Way Elbow. Please let me know if there is a fitting you need that I haven't created yet. You are highly encouraged to make new derivatives. Please tag your new creations with #HalfInchPVCFittings.

remixed_from.title: 3-Way Elbow, 1/2 Inch PVC Pipe Fitting Series #HalfInchPVCFittings - UPDATED 2015-02-02

title: 4-Way Tee & 5-Way Tee, 1/2 Inch PVC Pipe Fitting Series #HalfInchPVCFittings UPDATE 2015-07-03

description.text:
UPDATE 2015-07-03 - I tightened the tolerances slightly for a better fit. Make sure your printer is well calibrated before printing.  
Here are 4-Way and 5-Way Tees designed to fit 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe. They are part of a series of 1/2" PVC fittings I'm designing to supplement conventional plumbing fittings.   
I put the triangular holes in the pipes to help the glue dry. On the first iteration, I noticed that being air tight prohibited drying. The ledges on the top of the horizontal holes make it printable without support structures.   
I will continue to add new fittings to the series and share them as a derivative of my original 3-Way Elbow. Please let me know if there is a fitting you need that I haven't created yet.   
You are highly encouraged to make new derivatives. Please tag your new creations with #HalfInchPVCFittings.

comments.text: this may be a stupid question but im new to 3d printing how would i go about enlarging these for 1 inch pvc i want to build a desk frame with pvc pipe
comments.author: stweed

comments.text: Measure the outside diameter of the pipe in millimeters. Then scale the model to where the inside diameter of the fitting is .2 mms bigger than the outside diameter of the pipe. This would be easiest in the free version of Sketchup. It may take a few prints to perfect.

comments.text: Thanks! By the way, I included the .skp files in the download section for modifying these in Sketchup. Once you figure out the scale for one fitting, the same scale should work for all my other 1/2" fittings.

description.text: a Five-seveN model
a Five-seveN model

I was looking for other things to make with my Ninjaflex filament and also needed some "fashion" related items for a 3D printing demo I'm doing at work so....
Designed this small purse/clutch (measures 7"x4"x2.5") for my display after not finding exactly what I wanted here on Thingiverse. It fits a phone, small wallet, and I'm sure a lipstick or other womanly items. Not really my thing, but I think it turned out pretty good!

Printed on my Replicator 1 with Ninjaflex filament. Still trying to get the hang of this stuff... setting: temp 218, bed temp 60, speed 50, 2 shells, 10% fill. It took about 5 hrs. to print.
Walls are a bit thin. They buckled some about 2/3 the way up. I wasn't sure how thick to make them. I'll go back and thicken the walls and upload the modified file. I created in 123 Design, so feel free to modify it yourself. I'll probably add holes for a couple of D-rings to mount a strap on the outside of the clasps. I used small magnetic clasps from Jo-Ann's and covered them with rhinestones. (In the pictures they are just taped on...will epoxy them at work tomorrow.)

title: Servo Screw-Mounting Frame for Foamboard Airplanes

description.text:
If you're a fan of foamboard airplanes (like the popular Flite Test designs) you know that the usual way to mount servos into the foam is with hot glue. This works, but it's difficult and messy to remove the servos for repair or replacement or just to move them to a new plane.
Just glue these frames into your plane and you can mount your servos with the included screws. The frames provide hard points for the screws to grip and make it easy to remove the servos later.
These frames are sized for the popular HXT-900 9g servos and others with similar dimensions.

Just cut a hole in the foam board, push the frame part-way into the hole, squeeze some hot glue under the tabs and press it down flush.
You can press the frame lightly against the board to dent the paper, marking the area you need to cut.

Butter and bacon. Unfortunately, this design only works with one of them.  
Butter readily absorbs odors from your fridge and also can oxidize, making it taste.... off. The definition of "off" depends on what you have in your fridge, but I can vouch that fishy butter is gross. The waxy paper it is stored in normally prevents this process, but after you peel the wrapping off, you can never really fully seal it again. This cap seals the end of the stick makes sure that the wrapping won't accidentally open and expose the buttery goodness to that rotten onion in the back of your crisper drawer.  
Currently this only works for sticks butter that are 1.25"x1.25". For "western" sticks that are 1.5", scale by 120%.
Scale to fit and print

comments.text: This is a simple but great idea. I always want to cover the open end of the butter, since it so easily absorbs smells from the fridge, but putting the paper back on is kind of ineffective, and I don't like to put it in it's own Tupperware. Good work!
comments.author: PaulSJoyGlobal

author: jmalinski

description.text:
Designed to maintain lead screw alignment inline with stepper motor.
When I initially designed this I made a sleeve that fit in the bearing that reduced the opening to fit a 1/4" ACME screw.  I will update this design to include that piece as soon as I can.  I will also post another version of this design that is lower profile (3/17/2016).

Designed in OpenSCAD (file included, heavily commented making it easy to customize).
Mounts to 20mm (2020 or 2040) T-Slot Aluminum Extrusion using M5 bolts and square nuts (that fit slot in Aluminum T-Slot Extrusion).
Height is set to line up with drive shaft of NEMA 17 stepper motor. Bearing used is a 608 radial skate bearing.
Compression nut and bolt are M3
I am using this with a 1/4" single start Acme thread lead screw.
Printed in white PLA.

title: 8mm Guide Rod Holder for T-Slot Aluminum Extrusion

description.text:
Holds 8mm Guide Rod and mounts to 20mm Aluminum T-Slot Extrusion (designed to fit 20mm series T-Slot Aluminum Extrusion - 2020 or 2040). Mounts to aluminum extrusion using M5 bolts and square nuts (that fit T-slot of aluminum extrusion).
Guide rod center aligns with height of the center of the drive shaft of NEMA 17 stepper.
Compression screw and nut are M3.
Printed in white PLA

title: Prusa I3 Rework X-END-IDLER with Solidworks 2014 Source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
11/09/2014 - I found an error in the hole for the screw that holds the 624zz bearing as it was too small (strange as the original I have was the wrong size too) by 1mm as it was designed for a 3mm but should have been sized for a M4. This has been corrected and reuploaded in the two files.
.
.
I could not find any source files to work with for my I3 Rework so I am slowly making SW source files for them. All of them are painstakingly done by hand so may not be an identical copy. and/or may be missing something I overlooked, but are as close as I will get to the originals.
.
Last night I found this part broken as I had noticed my printing in the X direction was slightly funky. When I examined the printer I noticed my belt was slightly loose and upon closer inspection I see that the place for the M3 screw that holds the 624zz in was broken at the top and at the nut hole. I am not sure when this happenened so I got on the case to make this. It will hold me over until I strengthen it and add a belt tightener.
.
I am still doing these in SW 2014 until June then I will be switching up to 2015 that way others will have upgraded by then and still use my work.

Print this with a lot of infill or be warned it will eventually break. I think the person who made my kit used 15-25% infill and for this part that is just not enough.
Infill: 60%
Vertical Shells: 4
Horizontal Top and Bottom Shells: 6

author: boelene

description.text:
These are four corners I designed for my new 3dprinter.
During building my first 3dprinter I gained a lot of knowledge and came up with ideas to improve the initial design. I started to improve these corners. They support the steel rods for the y-carriage and support the bearings for the steel rods that drive the left x-carriage and the right x-carriage. (People who are familiar with the Replicator will know what I mean).
The bearings in the two corners at the back can be adjusted with a M3 screw. You can use 5mm (inside) x 16mm (outside) x 5mm (thickness) bearings.
The corner constructions will hold M3 nuts so they can be mounted to the side panels and front or back panel.
The corners are designed for 8mm steel rods.
Corner_RF = Right Front, LF = Left front, RB = Right Back, LB = Left Back.
Corner_RF will hold an optical end-stop.
For any questions please contact me.
For any questions please contact me.

author: thingster

description.text:
First of all many thanks to @aref_naa. He made the first version of these pieces, but they had incorrect rear sides, the promoted sides. I found out how to correct that and here they are.
The collection also includes both kings and a gold, but I didn't have an image. They didn't have to be corrected.
I use these to design a shogi set based on coloured pieces with original inscriptions. I detest using pieces with indications of how they move. You wouldn't do that for a chess piece would you?

I worked with Blender. I corrected the rear sides of the pieces by first replacing it with a flat surface. Then I made an svg drawing with Inkscape. I imported that into Blender. That results in a curve. I gave it thickness and I turned it into a mesh. Then I carved the symbol using the Boolean modifier with difference.

remixed_from.author: walter
remixed_from.title: Low Poly Frog Mount (RigidBot E3D v6)

description.text:
Experimental dual E3Dv6 mount for the RigidBot. Nozzle spacing is approximately 3cm along the X-axis. Parts:
2 - E3Dv6 Hotends
2 - 24V 40mm x 10mm axial fans
2 - 50mm x 15mm radial fans
1 - 24V COB LED Module (optional)
Additional connectors and wires M3 Screws:
Baseplate (8 - M3x16)
Fans (2 - M3x12, 2 - M3x16)
Clamps (4 - M3x10, 4 - M3x25, 4 - M3x16)
Duct (2 - M3x20, 1 - M3x10) Example dualstrusion prints from nervoussystem.

Width of the mount is 82mm, about the same size as the original RigidBot single extruder plate.  
Both 40mm fans are oriented the same direction (one blowing air in, the other out).  
I used the extruder fan power for the LED, but it's probably better to use a different 24V source.  The light flickers whenever the bed is heating (similar to the heated bed red led flickering).  
I replaced the heated bed screws with lower profile flathead screws so they'd be lower than the 2.5mm glass plate (prevents the nozzle from crashing into the bed leveling bolts).

comments.text: Have begun printing this, how should the gt2 belt be twisted when i install the finished parts? do i need the additional linear bearing? would have to disassemble less if i leave one out ;)
comments.author: BrOlleJonsson

comments.text: The belt should have half a twist on the far unconnected side, toothed part over the pulley, smooth side over the bearing.  I'd say give it a go with three bearings, most printers seem to go with three to avoid binding issues so it may even be better that way.
comments.author: BrOlleJonsson

comments.text:
Walter, how should we set support for Ducts? (I see you have oriented in a way minimizing supports) Where should we specifically focus on supports.
Thanks,
comments.author: janapriya

comments.text: For the smaller duct, putting support under parts where the screw holes will improve the quality there and reduce the odds of the part getting knocked over.  The larger one could probably use some on the horizontal bridge near the top, that part drooped a couple of mm when I printed it.
comments.author: janapriya

comments.text: @walter, what is your opinion on the rigidbot? Is it any where near as good as it sounds?
comments.author: robotsinc

comments.text: I really like my RigidBot.  I kickstarted it thinking there was no way I would get a decent printer for that price, but I figured it would be worth it just to have a solid frame and a bag of parts to play with.  I was definitely impressed with what I got, there was clearly a lot of time and effort put into the design of the printer.  Now, if I could only keep one of my printers, it would without doubt be the RigidBot.  The Afinia is great at what it does, but the larger build area, the ability to print almost anything (with the added E3D Hotend), and the increased configurability makes the RigidBot much more useful.
comments.author: robotsinc
